case_name: Appellant v. Kumbakonam Mutual Benefit Fund Ltd.

facts.text: The respondent is the Kumbakonam Mutual Benefit Fund Ltd., hereinafter referred to as the assessee, a company incorporated under the Indian Companies Act 1882, limited by shares.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, the Kumbakonam Mutual Benefit Fund Ltd., hereinafter referred to as the assessee, is a companypany incorporated under the Indian Companies Act. 1882, limited by shares.

facts.text: Since 1938, the nominal capital of the assessee is Rs. 33,00,000 divided into shares of Re. 1 each.

anchor.surface_text: Since 1938. the numberinal capital of the assessee is Rs. 33,00,000 divided into shares of Re. 1 each.

facts.text: The assessee carries on banking business restricted to its shareholders.

anchor.surface_text: It carries on banking business restricted to its shareholders, i.e., the shareholders are entitled to participate in the various recurring deposit schemes of the assessee or to obtain loans on security.

facts.text: Shareholders are entitled to participate in recurring deposit schemes or obtain loans on security.

anchor.surface_text: i.e., the shareholders are entitled to participate in the various recurring deposit schemes of the assessee or to obtain loans on security. The statement of the case describes the working of the assessee thus

facts.text: Recurring deposits are obtained from members for fixed amounts contributed monthly for a fixed number of months, at the end of which a fixed amount including compound interest is returned according to published tables.

anchor.surface_text: Recurring deposits are obtained from members for fixed amounts to be companytributed monthly by them for a fixed number of months as stipulated at the end of which a fixed amount is returned to them according to published tables.

facts.text: Recurring deposits constitute the main source of funds for advancing loans.

anchor.surface_text: The amount so returned will companyer the companypound interest of the period. These recurring deposits companystitute the main source of funds of the assessee for advancing loans.

facts.text: Loans are restricted to members who offer security by paid up value of recurring deposits or immovable properties in Tanjore district.

anchor.surface_text: Such loans are restricted only to members who have, however, to offer substantial security, therefor, by way of either the paid up value of their recurring deposits, if any, or immovable properties within the Tanjore district.

facts.text: Out of interest on loans (main income), interest on recurring deposits is paid, plus expenses, balance divided among members pro rata according to shareholdings after reserves.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the interest realised by the assessee on the loans which companystitute its main income, interest on the recurring deposits aforesaid are paid as also all the other outgoings and expenses of management and the balance is divided among the members pro rata according to their shareholdings after making provision for reserves, etc.

facts.text: Shareholders entitled to participate in profits need not have taken loans or made recurring deposits.

anchor.surface_text: The shareholders who are thus entitled to participate in the profits need number have either taken loans or have made recurring deposits.

facts.text: Income-Tax Officer assessed the entire profits for eight years from 1946-47 to 1953-54.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-Tax Officer assessed the entire profits for eight years from 1946-47 to 1953-54.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer held in order dated February 29, 1952 for 1947-48 that New York Life Assurance Company v. Styles does not apply.

Styles 1  did number apply to the facts of this case.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld the order of the Income Tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner, on appeal, upheld the order of the Income Tax Officer.

facts.text: Income Tax Appellate Tribunal held that the assessee is a banking concern assessable under Section 10.

anchor.surface_text: The Income Tax Appellate Tribunal held as follows The funds claim that it is in reality a mutual benefit society is untenable... treating the appellant as a banking companycern.

facts.text: Tribunal referred questions to High Court for assessment years 1946-47 to 1953-54 in Case Referred No. 78 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal, however, stated a companysolidated case in respect of the assessment years, 1946-47 to 1953-54, and referred the following questions to the High Court... Case Referred No. 78 of 1956.

facts.text: Madras High Court answered the question in the negative by judgment dated October 20, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated October 20, 1960, of the Madras High Court in Case Referred No. 78 of 1956.

facts.text: High Court awarded costs Rs. 250 to assessee and ordered refund of institution fee Rs. 100 per reference.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, for reasons which will be shortly stated, answered the question in the negative, and awarded companyts Rs. 250. It further ordered the refund to the assessee of the institu- tion fee of Rs. 100 for each of the references

facts.text: Supreme Court appeals are Civil Appeals Nos. 637644 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: May 7, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SIKRI J.

facts.text: There is no complete identity between contributors and participators in the assessee's funds.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, the companyplete identity between companytribu- tors and participators does number exist.

facts.text: Assessee's income derived from interest on loans to members, Government securities, rents, distributed as interest or dividends.

anchor.surface_text: The income of the assessee is derived from interest on loans lent to its members, interest on Government securities, rents from property, etc., and it is distributed to the members either in the shape of guaranteed interest or dividends or both.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income Tax v. Royal Western Indian Turf Club Ltd. 1

anchor.surface_text: Most of the cases, both English and Indian, bearing on the point under discussion, were reviewed by this Court in Commissioner of Income Tax v. Royal Western Indian Turf Club Ltd. 1 , and this relieves us of the task of reviewing all of them again. We however, shortly deal with those in which companypanies limited by shares were companycerned for they stand on a slightly different footing from companypanies limited by guarantee.
